ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: So much historical and political thought. Nietzsche!
Reading comprehensively and critically, participating in discussion (being a starter), writing solid expository papers.
Gained new insight into Western political thought.
speaking skills
Mostly similar things I mentioned in the other DS course evalutions!

I have learnt to distinguish between and recognize some key categories within political thought (e.g account of human nature; systematic vs non-systematic thinking; driving forces in history)  that will help me to continue to analyze and compare political thinkers in the future. Through my essay-writing I have become more proficient in synthesizing material from an array of sources into a coherent argument; I have improved in my ability to efficiently summarize and reconstruct the argument a political thinker is making in a given text and think of meaningful ways that their narrative can be criticized.
I learned how to close read historical texts, analyse rhetoric, learn with authors charitably and criticise them sharply, how to speak eloquently and write efficiently, and how to compare ideas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: STRENGTHS: Professor Thompson! is the best! Rank this seminar first! Best seminar leading I have ever experienced. WEAKNESSES: Drop Mill to a day and add Franz Fanon!
Well-facilitated seminar, strong paper feedback.
Strengths: interesting content, great discussions. Weaknesses: lack of direction in discussion sometimes; would help to have more instruction from prof
Strengths: facilitation
Similar to the other DS course evaluations I did!

Strengths: I think the balance of having one lecture / week providing an overarching framework or avenue for understanding the text and two discussion sections, where the students have time to interact more closely with the material and discuss what interested and puzzled them with their peers, works extremely well. 

To me, the most helpful and interesting lectures were those who both managed to touch upon a large part of the reading material (and thus helping the student grasp the key concepts/ideas that they have encountered with such rapidity) and provide a distinct reading of the text that brings in material and biography from outside the assigned reading to enhance the student's understanding of it. One example of such a lecture was the lecture on Arendt. 

I believe this was the first year that Douglass' 4th of July-speech was a part of the DS syllabus, but to me it worked extremely well. Douglass' distinct understanding of history connected him to other thinkers on the syllabus, and the speech-format related it back to Pericles' funeral oration in the first semester. Most importantly, it served an important complement to nuance the Tocqueville-reading of the U.S (similar to reading Marx after Mill!).

Weaknesses: I think the final exam in H&P is unnecessary hard, when compared to the ones in the literature and philosophy tracks respectively. The passage Id's are very short, which makes them more difficult to identify than the passages in literature, while the clear questions that replaces the passage id's in philosophy give the student a more fair chance of displaying as much of their relevant knowledge as possible. Having to write two essays instead of one in the remaining 1,5 hours just leads me to produce two mediocre essays rather than a longer, really good one, which I have energy to do in literature and philosophy.

Its strengths are the great professor, engaged peers, and depth and intensity of its focus on a limited topic (the texts). Although I understand it's the nature of the course, I would've loved more time to digest each text, since they began to blur together after a while.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Please do not drop DS. The second semester is incredible. It will be worth it, it will change the way you see the world.
Absolutely. DS is spectacular on its own, and Norma Thompson somehow makes it even better. Take DS with Professor Thompson. You will not regret it!
Yes, definitely. Prof. Thompson created a rigorous, challenging, and rewarding experience.
Yes if youre interested in Western political thought.

Absolutely! It provides a fascinating and diverse, yet impressively coherent introduction to political thought since Machiavelli. The readings are well-selected, thought-provoking and all contribute to increasing the students' understanding of political thought. You are provided with an amazing opportunity to discuss some of the central questions within political thought together with intelligent, passionate peers and knowledgable, inspiring faculty members.

Absolutely. Professor Thompson is fantastic, and the peers are supportive and instructive themselves. I feel more confident in my own reading and writing abilities. Most importantly, I learned a ton about these fascinating and foundational texts.
